contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the time when God will put his people back in the land of Israel. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the day of Jezreel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “knowledge” refers to the knowledge of God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: knowledge

contextId.occurrenceNote: When people sinned, they would offer sacrifices so God would forgive them. The priests were allowed to eat these sacrifices. The priests eating these sacrifices for sin is spoken of as if they would actually feed on the people’s sins. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They feed on the sin of my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The priests want the people to sin more so that the people will offer more sacrifices that the priests may eat. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they are greedy for more of their wickedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people are selling and buying products dishonestly. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: for they practice deceit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jacob wanted to take his brother’s place as the firstborn, so he tried to keep his brother from being born first. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: In the womb Jacob grasped his brother by the heel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jacob fought with an angel so that the angel would bless him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: He struggled with the angel and won

contextId.occurrenceNote: Part of idol worship was kissing idol figures that were images of calves. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: These men who sacrifice kiss calves

contextId.occurrenceNote: This probably means words of confession and praise. Alternate translation: “Confess your sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Take with you words

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in modern units. Alternate translation: “330 liters of barley” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]])
contextId.quoteString: a homer and a lethek of barley

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Beeri

contextId.occurrenceNote: The events in this book happened during the time of these kings. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Uzziah & Jotham & Ahaz & Hezekiah & Jeroboam & Joash

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Gomer & Diblaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This name means “no mercy.” The translator may choose to represent this meaning as the name. Alternate translation: “No Mercy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Lo-Ruhamah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This name means “not my people.” The translator may choose to represent this meaning as the name. Alternate translation: “Not My People” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Lo-Ammi

contextId.occurrenceNote: This name means “you are my people.” The translator may choose to represent this meaning as the name. Alternate translation: “You Are My People” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Ammi Attah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was a city on the border between the northern kingdom of Israel and the tribe of Benjamin in the southern kingdom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Beth Aven

contextId.occurrenceNote: A snare and a net are both objects used to catch prey. In this case, the priests and the royal household had devised ways to keep the people away from Yahweh, while enticing them into idolatry. Mizpah and Tabor were places for idol worship in the land of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You have been a snare at Mizpah and a net spread over Tabor

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a mountain in the land of Moab where the false god Baal was worshiped. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Baal Peor

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a king who destroyed the city of Beth Arbel around 740 BC. His army murdered women and children in the attack. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Shalman

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is likely the name of a city of the tribe of Naphtali. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Beth Arbel

contextId.occurrenceNote: By loving the adulterous woman, Hosea will be an example of Yahweh’s love for Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Love her just as I, Yahweh, love the people of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exclamation may be presented as a statement. Alternate translation: “You are my people!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclamations]])
contextId.quoteString: My people!

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: People do not normally speak to things that cannot think or hear them. Translators may choose to have a different format for this passage if their languages do not allow such speech. Alternate translation: “The people will say, ‘We wish the mountains would cover us!’ and ‘We wish the hills would fall on us!’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: The people will say to the mountains, “Cover us!” and to the hills, “Fall on us!”

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “horn” and “trumpet” mean the same thing. This command is given to the people of Gibeah and Ramah to emphasize that the enemy is coming. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Blow the horn in Gibeah, and the trumpet in Ramah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sharp briers” and “thorns” mean the same thing. To have briers and thorns growing represents a land that has become desolate and like a wilderness. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: sharp briers will possess them, and thorns will fill their tents

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “prophet” and “inspired man” both mean a person who claims to receive messages from God. It is implied that these people are false prophets and only thought they received messages from God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The prophet is a fool, and the inspired man is insane

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases “great iniquity” and “great hostility” share similar meanings. The iniquity of the people manifested itself in hostility towards Yahweh and his prophets. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: because of your great iniquity and great hostility

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “And the people of Israel will be very ashamed because they had worshiped idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim will be disgraced, and Israel will be ashamed of its idol

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” and “Jacob” both represent the people of Judah. Alternate translation: “against the people of Judah … punish them for what they have done … repay them for their deeds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: against Judah & punish Jacob for what he has done & repay him for his deeds

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that the people of Ephraim consider themselves to be blameless. Learning that someone has sinned is spoken of as finding sin in that person. Alternate translation: “they will not discover that I have done anything sinful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they will not find any iniquity in me, anything that would be sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “would attack” are left out because they are understood. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “like a bear would attack an animal that takes her cubs” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: as a bear that is robbed of her cubs

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “would devour them” are left out because they are understood. Alternate translation: “as a lion would devour them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: as a lion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to “fall” represents dying. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: They will fall

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “the word that Yahweh God spoke” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh that came

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two kingdoms will become completely disobedient to God because of their pride and sin. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: so Israel and Ephraim will stumble in their guilt; and Judah also will stumble with them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents a short period of time. Israel believes God will quickly come to rescue them from their enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: After two days he will revive us; he will raise us up on the third day

contextId.occurrenceNote: This probably means to unite or join with someone. It may mean that the king joins with his officials to mock things or people that should not be mocked, even God himself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: He reached out with his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “head” refers to the part of the plant where the grain is. A stalk with no head has nothing to give to the farmer. In the same way, Israel’s actions will result in nothing good. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The standing grain has no heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “empty words” refers to lies. Alternate translation: “They speak lies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: They speak empty words

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “son of” is an idiom that means “having the characteristic of.” Alternate translation: “those who do wrong” or “the evildoers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the sons of wrong

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “prostitution” represents the people being unfaithful to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: great prostitution

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” means “family,” including Jehu’s descendants. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Jehu

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression refers to kingdom of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mother” refers to the nation of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is stating that Israel, spoken of here as a woman, is no longer acting like a wife to Yahweh. Instead Israel has turned away from following and worshiping him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for she is not my wife

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh can no longer be in relationship with the nation of Israel as a husband would be to his wife. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: neither am I her husband

contextId.occurrenceNote: A wife who is adulterous leaves her husband to sleep with another man. This is how Israel was acting toward Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: her acts of adultery

contextId.occurrenceNote: This imagery suggests that Israel is relying on the idols and not Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: from between her breasts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will no longer protect and provide for Israel because the nation has turned away from him. In Israel, husbands were obliged by law to provide clothes for their wives. Not to do so was a sign that a man was rejecting his wife. The full meaning of this may be made clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will strip her naked and show her nakedness as on the day that she was born

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “thirst” refers to the need to worship and rely on Yahweh, not idols, or Israel will not be able to survive as a nation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make her die from thirst

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Israelites are acting like they do not belong to Yahweh. Just as their parents did not worship God, Neither do they. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for they are children of prostitution

contextId.occurrenceNote: The previous generation who sought out other gods were considered prostitutes for they were unfaithful to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For their mother has been a prostitute

contextId.occurrenceNote: This passage indicates that Yahweh will prevent his people from finding success and prosperity, becuase they continue to worship idols. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Therefore I will build up a hedge to block her way with thorns &  will build up a wall against her so she cannot find her way

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israel will return to Yahweh not because of their love for him, but because they are disappointed by their worship of Baal. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Then she will say, “I will return to my first husband, for it was better for me then than it is now.”

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to payment that Israel received from the false gods or Baals. This direct quotation can be stated as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: “that these were the wages that her lovers had given to her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
contextId.quoteString: These are the wages that my lovers gave me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will destroy the vineyards and fruit trees by allowing other trees and weeds to grow among them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: make them a forest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh hopes that the nation of Israel will repent and again choose to worship him as their God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: She will answer me there as she did in the days of her youth, as in the days that she came out of the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the people of Israel will love and be faithful to Yahweh just as a wife is to a husband. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: My husband

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Baal” means “master” and also refers to the false god that the Canaanites worship. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: My Baal

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will be like the husband, and Israel will be like Yahweh’s wife. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will promise to be your husband forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the name of this valley stands for all the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Jezreel

contextId.occurrenceNote: When God makes his people safe and prosperous in their land again, they are spoken of if they were agricultural crops. Alternate translation: “I will take care of the Israelite people as a farmer plants his crops and takes care of them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will plant her for myself in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh stating that the people of Israel have sinned against him and broken his covenant is spoken of as if Yahweh were accusing them in court. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh has a lawsuit against the inhabitants of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bounds” stands for the limits of what the law allows. Alternate translation: “The people have disobeyed the law in every possible way” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The people have broken all bounds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “stumble” means to disobey God or even to stop trusting him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You priests will stumble

contextId.occurrenceNote: has convinced the people to sin (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: has misled

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will destroy the nation of Israel because they do not understand or obey God’s commandments. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: So this people who does not understand will be thrown down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that he cannot continue to take care of the people because they are stubborn. Yahweh no longer taking care of his people is spoken of as if he were a shepherd that could not take his lambs into the field to eat because they are stubborn. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will not shepherd a rebellious people.” or “Therefore Yahweh will not continue to take care of them.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: How can Yahweh bring them to pasture like lambs in a meadow?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “wind” represents God’s judgment and anger against the nation of Israel. Yahweh will allow the enemy army to defeat the people of Israel and take them as captives. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The wind will wrap her up in its wings

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “rebels” refers to all of those people who had turned away from Yahweh, and “deep in slaughter” could refer to the murder of innocent people, or to the slaughter of animals offered to pagan idols. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The rebels stand deep in slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s wrath against Judah will be like a large stream of water that destroys them. In the scriptures, emotions and moral qualities are often spoken of as if they were liquids. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will pour my wrath on them like water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “walked” represents the idea of worshiping. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: walked after idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both Ephraim (the northern kingdom of Israel) and Judah (the southern kingdom of Israel) realized that they were in danger. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: When Ephraim saw his sickness, and Judah saw his wound

contextId.occurrenceNote: As a lion tears apart the animal it is eating, so Yahweh will tear his people away from their homes and country. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will tear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Try to come into God’s presence by means of worship and sacrifice. Alternate translation: “ask me to pay attention to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: seek my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Through his prophets, Yahweh has pronounced destruction on the rebellious nation. The destruction, here called “cutting to pieces,” is as sure as the condemnation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: So I have cut them to pieces by the prophets

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “harvest” represents God’s final judgment on Israel and Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: harvest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Making Israel obedient to God again and receivers of his blessing is spoken of as if it were healing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I want to heal Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people’s evil deeds are probably spoken of here as if they were other people ready to accuse them of their crimes. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their deeds surround them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people committed spiritual adultery by worshiping idols and being unfaithful to Yahweh. They were probably also being unfaithful to their husbands or wives by sleeping with other people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They are all adulterers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “smolders” means something is burning slowly without a flame. Alternate translation: “Their anger grows slowly and quietly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Their anger smolders

contextId.occurrenceNote: This seems to mean that the court officials kill their kings. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they devour those who rule over them

contextId.occurrenceNote: However, this “old age” is clearly a way of saying that the northern kingdom is getting weaker and weaker, because the nation does not know it is “old.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: but he does not know it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israel’s lack of interest in Yahweh is spoken of as if he was lost and they were not trying to find him. Alternate translation: “nor have they tried to get him to pay attention to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: nor have they sought him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a way to catch birds. Yahweh continues to compare the people of Israel to doves. When they go to Egypt or Assyria for help, Yahweh will punish them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will spread my net over them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here no longer worshiping God is spoken of as turning away from him. Alternate translation: “they no longer worship me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they turn away from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may be a military metaphor, in which God training the Israelites to love him and obey him is spoken of as if he had been training their men for war. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Though I trained them and strengthened their arms

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eagle, a bird of prey, is sometimes used to represent the enemies of Israel. Alternate translation: “As an eagle hunts another animal, the enemies of Israel are coming to capture my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: An eagle is coming over the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “broken” represents “disobeyed,” “violated.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: broken my covenant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Anger is often spoken of as if it were a fire. Alternate translation: “I am very angry with these people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: My anger is burning against these people

contextId.occurrenceNote: To sow or plant the wind is to act in useless or destructive ways. To reap the whirlwind is to suffer disaster from one’s own actions. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For the people sow the wind and reap the whirlwind

contextId.occurrenceNote: If any of Israel’s actions do happen to result in something good, Israel’s enemies will come and take it from them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: If it does come to maturity, foreigners will devour it

contextId.occurrenceNote: “swallowed” means to be defeated and taken into exile. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The enemies of Israel have taken the Israelites away to other lands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel is swallowed up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ephraim’s alliances with other nations are spoken of as if they had paid them to become prostitutes for Ephraim. Alternate translation: “The people of Israel have tried to pay other nations to protect them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim has hired lovers for herself

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is food that the Israelites would normally refuse to eat because it would make them unacceptable to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: unclean food

contextId.occurrenceNote: Briers growing in the places where Israelites stored their silver is spoken of as if the briers were human enemies that would take the Israelite’s precious possessions for themselves. Alternate translation: “Sharp briers will grow where they store their treasures of silver” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: As for their treasures of silver—sharp briers will possess them

contextId.occurrenceNote: A “watchman” watches outside his city to see if danger is coming. The prophet warning the people when they are sinning and are in danger of having his God punish them is spoken of as if he were a watchman for the city. Alternate translation: “The prophet is like a watchman for God over Ephraim” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The prophet is the watchman for my God over Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: A “bird snare” is a trap used to catch a bird. This means the people of Israel do whatever they can to stop God’s prophet. Alternate translation: “the people set a trap for him wherever he goes” or “the people do all they can to harm him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a bird snare is on all of his paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: When God stops helping the northern kingdom, it will be as if he physically turned away from them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when I turn away from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people being in a safe place as if they were a tree planted in a peaceful meadow. Alternate translation: “The nation of Israel was once beautiful and pleasant like the city of Tyre, like a tree that someone plants in a meadow” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have seen Ephraim, just like Tyre, planted in a meadow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people of Israel as if they were a diseased tree that does not produce fruit and is ready to be cut down. This is a statement that the people have become weak, and that soon their enemies will come and defeat them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim is diseased, and their root is dried up; they bear no fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israel is spoken of as a vine that was very fruitful. For a while the people prospered and were strong. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel is a luxuriant vine that produces his fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: What they people called justice in their laws and legal decisions is spoken of as if it were a plant sprouting up. Alternate translation: “So their decisions are not just; instead, they are harmful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: So justice springs up like poisonous weeds in the furrows of a field

contextId.occurrenceNote: This passage probably means that the people of the present time continue to act in the same ways that their ancestors did at Gibeah. Alternate translation: “and you think just as they did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: there you have remained

contextId.occurrenceNote: A heifer loves to thresh because they can walk around freely without a yoke. Yahweh means that he has allowed the people of Israel to be free and have a pleasant life. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim is a trained heifer that loves to thresh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “yoke” refers to suffering and slavery. Yahweh has been kind to the people of Israel, but the people have been unfaithful to him. So he will punish them and send them away as slaves. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will put a yoke on her fair neck &  will put a yoke on Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” refers to the people of the southern kingdom and “Jacob” is the people of the northern kingdom. This means God will cause difficult times for both kingdoms. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah will plow; Jacob will pull the harrow by himself

contextId.occurrenceNote: Righteousness and covenant faithfulness are spoken of as if they were crops that could be sown and harvested. The abstract nouns “righteousness” and “faithfulness” can be stated as “right” and “faithful.” Alternate translation: “Plow, now, and do what is right, and you will reap the fruit of faithful love” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Sow righteousness for yourselves, and reap the fruit of covenant faithfulness

contextId.occurrenceNote: When the ground is “unplowed” it is not ready to be planted. Yahweh means he wants the people to repent so they can start doing what is right. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Break up your unplowed ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wickedness and injustice are spoken of as if they were crops that could be sown and harvested. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You have plowed wickedness; you reaped injustice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The result of deception are spoken of as if they were a food that could be eaten. Alternate translation: “You now suffer the consequences of having deceived each other” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You have eaten the fruit of deception

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking about the people of Israel as if they were a young man. Yahweh is referring to when he first started his relationship with the nation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: When Israel was a young man

contextId.occurrenceNote: “son” refers to the people of God the Father. Alternate translation: “I led my son out of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I called my son out of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh refers to Israel as a small child whom he taught to walk. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it was I who taught Ephraim to walk

contextId.occurrenceNote: Worshiping and honoring Yahweh is spoken of as if it were following him (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They will follow Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Becoming wealthy by trading is spoken of as finding wealth. Alternate translation: “I have made much money” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have found wealth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idea of making someone suffer the results of his own actions is spoken of as if those actions were objects that were thrown back at him. Alternate translation: “will make him suffer from his own disgraceful actions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will turn back on him his disgrace

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “exalting” means to make oneself important. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He exalted himself in Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: When the people of Ephraim began worshiping Baal, they grew weak, and their enemies defeated them. Here “died” refers to the nation growing weak. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: but he became guilty because of Baal worship, and he died

contextId.occurrenceNote: Becoming arrogant is spoken of as one’s heart being lifted up. Alternate translation: “you became proud” (See:[[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your heart became lifted up

contextId.occurrenceNote: The northern kingdom’s iniquity and guilt are spoken of as if they were objects that could be kept for a purpose. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: has been stored up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks of the suffering the people of Israel will suffer as if it were the pains of child birth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Pains of childbirth will come on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh now describes the people of Israel as the baby to which the mother is giving birth. The baby is unwise because it does not want to be born. The people do not want to repent and obey Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: but he is an unwise son, for when it is time to be born, he does not come out of the womb

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not to think about having compassion is spoken of as if compassion were hidden so that it cannot be seen. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **compassion**, you can express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “I have no compassion for them” or “I will not be compassionate towards them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Compassion is hidden from my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression seems to stand for the nations around the northern kingdom, especially Judah, the southern kingdom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: his brothers

contextId.occurrenceNote: A wind from the east was very hot and destructive. Here it refers to the armies from the east that Yahweh will send to destroy the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: an east wind will come; the wind of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hosea continues to describe how God will punish the people of Israel. Here water represents life, vitality, and strength. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim’s spring will dry up, and his well will have no water

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all of the peoples’ possessions. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: his storehouse

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sinning is spoken of here as if it were falling. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for you have fallen because of your iniquity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Stopping the people from turning away from God is spoken of as if he were healing them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will heal their turning away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The failure of the people to obey God is spoken of as if they had physically turned away from him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their turning away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel will once again live protected by God. Israel is spoken of as living in his shade. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The people who live in his shade will return

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “fruit” represents every good thing that comes from Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: from me comes your fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s commandments are spoken of as ways to walk in. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For the ways of Yahweh are right, and the righteous will walk in them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Disobeying Yahweh is spoken of as if it were stumbling while walking. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: stumble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bow” refers to the power of the army. Alternate translation: “the military power of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the bow of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “my lovers” refers to Baal and other false gods, whom Israel has chosen to worship instead of Yahweh. The list of things are essential items that allow the people to live. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will go after my lovers, for they give me my bread and water, my wool and flax, my oil and drink

contextId.occurrenceNote: This probably means that Israel’s harvests and flocks will fail. Yahweh will remove his blessings from Israel, and the people will be left alone and in danger of attack. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will take back my wool and flax that were used to cover her nakedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: No one will try to help Israel. Here “hand” refers to God’s power to punish. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: no one will rescue her out of my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will keep Israel’s enemies away from them, there will be no more war, the people will be safe. Here “the bow, the sword, and the battle” represent war. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will drive away the bow, the sword, and the battle from the land, and I will make you lie down in safety

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression refers to living in safety. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: lie down in safety

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “David” represents all the descendants of David. Alternate translation: “a descendant of David to be their king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: David their king

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “trembling” represents feelings of awe and humility. Alternate translation: “they will come back to Yahweh and will humble themselves, honor him, and ask for his blessings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they will come trembling before Yahweh and his goodness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “honor” is a metonym that represents Yahweh, and “shame” is a metonym that represents idols. Alternate translation: “They have stopped worshiping me, their honorable God, and now worship shameful idols” or (2) some Bible versions translate this as “I will exchange their honor for shame.” This means Yahweh will take away the things which the priests honor and cause the priests to be ashamed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They exchanged their honor for shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this refers to Adam, the first man or (2) this is a metonym that represents the people who live in a city in Israel called Adam. Alternate translation: “Like the people in the city of Adam” or (3) this refers to people in general. The word “Adam” means “man” or “humankind.” Alternate translation: “Like all of humankind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Like Adam

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Footprints of blood” probably represents the evildoers and their acts of murder. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Gilead is a city & with footprints of blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “prostitution” refers to Ephraim’s worship of false gods. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim’s prostitution

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “gray hairs” represent old age. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Gray hairs are sprinkled on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “tongue” refers to what the officials say. Alternate translation: “because they insult me” or “because they curse me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: because of the insolence of their tongues

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people worshiped an idol that looked like a calf, so Yahweh is speaking of their worship as if it were the calf itself. Alternate translation: “Because you worship your calf idol, your worship” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Your calf

contextId.occurrenceNote: Egypt and Memphis refer to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “the army of Egypt will capture you. You will die there, and the people in the city of Memphis will bury you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Egypt will gather them, and Memphis will bury them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “tents” represents the Israelites’ homes. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: their tents

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “children” are the people from that nation. Alternate translation: “but the people of Israel will bring out their children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: but Ephraim will bring out his children

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is stating that he will force Israel out of his land, the land of Canaan. Here “my house” represents Canaan. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will drive them out of my house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “guilt” is a metonym for the punishment that is associated with it. This punishment is spoken of as if it was a heavy load for them to carry. Alternate translation: “now is the time that Yahweh will punish them for their sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: now they must bear their guilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Bethel” represents the people who live there. The prophet addresses the people of Bethel as if they were there listening to him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: So it will happen to you, Bethel, because of your great wickedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents the enemies of Israel who will destroy Israel’s cities. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The sword will fall on their cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gates offered security to city inhabitants from their enemies, and the bars secured the closed gates. To destroy the bars meant to take away the people’s security. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: destroy the bars of their gates

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents God’s will and decisions. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: My heart has changed within me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” refers to the people who live there. This speaks of being loyal to God as “going about” with him. However, many versions have different interpretations of this difficult passage. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: But Judah is still going about with me

contextId.occurrenceNote: East winds were very hot and destructive to the land. Here it represents anything that is destructive. The people doing things that will destroy themselves is spoken of as if they are following the east wind. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: follows after the east wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) Yahweh is threatening to force the people of Israel from their homes and make them live in tents. So, here to “live in tents” would represent being sent into exile, or (2) it is a promise that after their exile the people will live in tents again, and Yahweh will take care of them as he did when the Israelites left Egypt. So, here “to live in tents” would represent a return to an ideal situation when Yahweh took care of his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will again make you live in tents

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” refers to the guilt incurred by people who murder others. God will not forgive their sins. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: So his Lord will leave his blood on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Samaria” refers to the people in the city of Samaria who are guilty of rebelling against God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Samaria will be guilty, for she has rebelled against her God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “sword” represents the enemy soldiers who used swords in battle. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: What a person says is called the fruit of his lips. Modern versions have different translations of this difficult passage. Alternate translation: “our words and songs of praise” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the fruit of our lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. This statement is made twice for emphasis. Here “Ephraim” refers to the people of the northern kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: “I will punish the people of Israel severely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim is crushed; he is crushed in judgment

contextId.occurrenceNote: God has punished the people of Israel because they disobeyed him and worshiped idols. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: he has torn us to pieces & he has injured us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israel believes that God will be merciful to them when they repent and he will deliver them from their troubles. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: he will heal us & he will bandage our wounds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: the day of an appointed festival & the day of a festival for Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hosea says these two similar phrases to emphasize that Yahweh will soon judge the people of Israel for their evil deeds. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: The days for punishment are coming; the days for retribution are coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing. This could mean: (1) that the people regarded the prophets as madmen or (2) that the prophets had become crazy because of the sins that the people had committed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: The prophet is a fool, and the inspired man is insane

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these statements emphasize situations that are pleasing to a person. This means Yahweh was very happy when his relationship with the people of Israel started. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: it was like finding grapes in the wilderness & ike the very first fruit of the season on the fig tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh loved his people in ways that they as humans could understand and appreciate. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I led them with cords of humanity, with bands of love

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lies and deceitful acts are spoken of as if they were objects that the people of the northern kingdom surrounded Yahweh with. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim surrounds me with falsehood, and the house of Israel with deceit

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and mean that the people of Ephraim consider themselves to be very prosperous. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I have certainly become very rich; I have found wealth for myself

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are similar and mean basically the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim’s iniquity has been stored up; his guilt has been stored up

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land will meet the need for grain, new wine, and olive oil. These things will also meet the needs of Jezreel. The land and these products are spoken of as if they were people who could meet the needs of others. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: The earth will answer the grain, the new wine and the oil, and they will answer Jezreel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel are pursuing sex outside of marriage and drinking too much wine. In doing these activities they have forgotten Yahweh’s commands. These actions are spoken of here as if they were someone who could prevent other people from understanding the importance of obeying Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: sexual promiscuity, wine, and new wine, which have taken away their understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: Idol worshipers used walking sticks to help them predict the future. The walking sticks are spoken of here as if they were people who spoke prophecies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: their walking sticks give them prophecies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Worshiping the idols and sleeping with the temple prostitutes has developed in the people of Israel the desire to always sin against Yahweh in these ways. Here “mind” is spoken of as if it were a separate person who was able to convince the people to disobey Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: a mind of promiscuity has misled them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes “pride” as a person who testifies against the people of Israel in court. Their prideful attitude and behavior show that they are guilty of no longer obeying Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: The pride of Israel testifies against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel were supposed to celebrate during the new moon. Here this expression seems to describe the new moon festival as a beast that will eat the people and their fields. However, it is hard to interpret this expression; many versions translate it without making much sense of it. However, the overall meaning is certainly that God will punish the people for their unfaithfulness to him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Now the new moon festivals will devour them with their fields

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes “pride” as a person who testifies against the people of Israel in court. This means their prideful attitude and behavior show that they are guilty of no longer obeying Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: The pride of Israel testifies against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes the threshing floor and the winepress as if they were humans that can feed someone. This means that the harvest will not provide enough grain for threshing to meet the needs of the people, and that it will not provide the grapes for pressing to make enough wine. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: But the threshing floor and the winepress will not feed them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The unclean food is spoken of as if it were able to go places by itself. Of course, people actually had to take it with them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: it will not come into the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks to “death” and “Sheol” as if they were people. Yahweh uses questions to say that he will destroy the people soon. Alternate translation: “Now I will cause plagues and let the people of Israel die. I will destroy them and send them to Sheol.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Where, death, are your plagues? Where, Sheol, is your destruction?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is expressing that his patience is coming to an end and what remains is judgment. Alternate translation: “it is hard to know what to do with you!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: what will I do with you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to express his anger about his people being impure. “I am angry with these people because they have no desire to be innocent.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: For how long will they stay guilty?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hosea uses this question to emphasize that the people will no longer be able to observe their festivals when their enemies defeat them and take them captive. Alternate translation: “You will not be able to celebrate the festivals that Yahweh appointed for you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What will you do on the day of an appointed festival, on the day of a festival for Yahweh?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hosea uses a question to emphasize that he wants Yahweh to give the people of Israel what they deserve. Alternate translation: “This is what I ask you, Yahweh, to give them: give them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Give them, Yahweh—what will you give them? Give them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people wills say that their kings could not have helped them. Alternate translation: “Even if we had a king now, he could not help us.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: and a king—what could he do for us?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that those in Gibeah who do wrong will certainly have to endure war. And this speaks of the people having to endure war when their enemies come as if war were a person that would catch up with them. Alternate translation: “War will certainly come on those who do wrong in Gibeah.” or “Enemies will certainly attack those who do wrong in Gibeah.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Will not war overtake the sons of wrong in Gibeah?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question means that the nation of Israel will once again be slaves as they were in Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will they not return to the land of Egypt?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The nation of Israel will be captives of Assyria as a result of their refusal to remain faithful to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will Assyria not rule over them because they refuse to return to me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh loves his people so much that he will not totally destroy them. These questions may be translated as statements. Alternate translation: “I will not give you up, Ephraim. I will not hand you over, Israel.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: How can I give you up, Ephraim? How can I hand you over, Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh loves his people so much that he will not totally destroy them. These questions may be translated as statements. Alternate translation: “I do not want to act toward you as I acted toward Admah or make you like Zeboyim—cities that I destroyed along with Sodom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: How can I make you like Admah? How can I make you like Zeboyim?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that no one will be able to help the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “there will be no on able to help you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: who will be able to help you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks these questions to tell Israel that when they rebel against him, no king or ruler can help them. Only Yahweh can save them from destruction. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Where now is your king, that he may save you in all your cities? Where are your rulers, about whom you said to me, ‘Give me a king and princes’?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses these questions to tell the people of Israel that he is not going to save them from dying. He will certainly punish them. Alternate translation: “I will certainly not rescue them from death and from going down to Sheol.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Will I rescue them from the hand of Sheol? Will I rescue them from death?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This passage signifies that God will stop the people of Israel from worshiping idols any longer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: what more have I to do with idols?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet uses these questions to say that wise people will understand and listen to what has been said to them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Who is wise that he may understand these things? Who understands these things so that he may know them?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes the great number of Israelites. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like the sand of the seashore

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will change Israel to resemble the wilderness, which is a region that is bare and unproductive. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make her like the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israel is compared to a young cow that will not obey its master. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a stubborn heifer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ephraim is presented in terms of a prostitute because the people have become unfaithful to God, as a prostitute is faithful to no man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim, now you have become like a prostitute

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “move a boundary stone” refers to moving the landmark that marked the border of some property, which was a crime under Israelite law. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: The leaders of Judah are like those who move a boundary stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: A moth on a piece of wool and rot in a piece of wood are both destructive. Yahweh will destroy both nations. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I will be like a moth to Ephraim, and like rot to the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is going to pursue and attack Ephraim like a lion. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: So I will be like a lion to Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is going to treat Judah in a similar way. Yahweh is showing his displeasure with both the northern and the southern kingdoms. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a young lion to the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will come to help his people just as surely as the sun rises each morning. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: His coming out is as sure as the dawn

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the prophet Hosea is speaking to God. He may mean that when God gives the command for someone to die as punishment, it is like a bolt of lightning that strikes. Or he may mean that God’s commandments allow people to know the truth, just as light makes objects visible. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Your decrees are like the light that shines out

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. This means the people had strong desires to do evil. Alternate translation: “like an oven which the baker heats” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: like an oven heated by the baker

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means like a fire burns in an oven, these people have strong evil desires within them. The people’s desires are represented by their “hearts.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For with hearts like an oven

contextId.occurrenceNote: The intensity of their anger is spoken of as if it was a very hot fire. Alternate translation: “it gets very intense” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: it burns high like a flaming fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares their anger to the heat that comes from an oven. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: They all are as hot as an oven

contextId.occurrenceNote: Doves were thought to be foolish birds. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim is like a dove, gullible and without sense

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the way he will judge Israel as if they were birds that he would catch in a net. Alternate translation: “I will hunt them like birds” or “I will catch them like a hunter catches birds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring them down like the birds of the sky

contextId.occurrenceNote: That is, a bow that has no bowstring, or that has no tension. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: They are like a slack bow

contextId.occurrenceNote: People often think of donkeys as being stubborn. This means the people of Israel refused to listen to Yahweh but instead went to the people of Assyria for help. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a wild donkey all alone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mourners’ food” refers to what people would eat while they mourning because they were defiled and not acceptable to God. This means Yahweh will consider the people’s sacrifices to be defiled and he will not accept them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Their sacrifices will be to them like mourners’ food

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Ephraim, or the northern kingdom of Israel, will lose everything that makes other nations respect them. Their glory will quickly disappear, as a bird flies away. Alternate translation: “their glory will be like a bird that flies away from them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: their glory will fly away like a bird

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their lies and injustice spread throughout their nation and harm everyone like poisonous plants. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like poisonous weeds in the furrows of a field

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the king of Samaria will be as helpless as a small piece of wood that waves of the water toss back and forth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a chip of wood on the surface of the water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking of the nation of Israel as a hardworking animal whose work he made easier. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I was to them like someone who eased the yoke on their jaws

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh making it possible for his people to return to his land is spoken of as if he were calling to his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: he will roar like a lion

contextId.occurrenceNote: They will come home quickly as a bird returns to its nest. “Trembling” may refer to the fluttering of a bird’s wings. It may also signal the people’s feelings of humility and reverence for God (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: They will come trembling like a bird & like a dove

contextId.occurrenceNote: The altars where the people worshiped will be thrown down and become piles of stones. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: their altars will be like heaps of stone in the furrows of the fields

contextId.occurrenceNote: These expressions state that Israel is temporary and will soon disappear if they continue to worship idols instead of following Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: So they will be like the morning clouds & like the dew & like the chaff & like smoke out of a chimney

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are wild animals that attack and kill other animals. Yahweh continues to say that he will destroy his people for their sins. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a lion & like a leopard

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are wild animals that attack and kill other animals. Yahweh continues to say that he will destroy his people for their sins. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as a bear & as a lion & as a wild beast

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is spoken of as if he were dew that brought needed moisture to plants, and Israel is spoken of as if it were one person, and as if he were a flower that could blossom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will be like the dew to Israel; he will blossom like the lily

contextId.occurrenceNote: The picture of Israel in the form of a plant is continued here, but this time in the form of a tall cedar tree in Lebanon, which was known for such trees. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: take root like a cedar in Lebanon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This passage continues the same image. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: His branches will spread out & like the cedars in Lebanon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israel’s new prosperity is spoken of in agricultural terms. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: they will revive like grain and blossom like vines

contextId.occurrenceNote: Just as Lebanon’s wine was famous, so Israel will be famous. Alternate translation: “People everywhere will know about the nation of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: His fame will be like the wine of Lebanon

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cypress is a tree whose leaves stay green all year. This represents Yahweh and his blessings on Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: a cypress whose leaves are always green

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Israelites will not speak the names of Baal and the idols again. The people are represented by their mouths. Alternate translation: “For I will cause you to not speak the names of the Baals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: For I will remove the names of the Baals from her mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Ephraim” represents the whole northern kingdom of Israel, which is a metonym for the people who live there. They chose to worship idols, instead of Yahweh. Yahweh is commanding Hosea to not try to correct them. The people of Israel will not listen. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim united himself with idols; leave him alone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, “Ephraim” and “Israel” both refer to the whole northern kingdom of Israel, and represent the people who live there. Here God says that he knows what they are like and what they are doing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I know Ephraim, and Israel is not hidden from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Benjamin” represents the soldiers from the tribe of Benjamin. This may be a request for them to lead the people into battle. But modern versions make various attempts to interpret this expression. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Sound a battle cry at Beth Aven: ‘We will follow you, Benjamin!’

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God is represented by his “face” which emphasizes his presence and awareness. Alternate translation: “and I see it all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: they are before my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Here “Ephraim” refers to the northern kingdom of Israel. The nation is weak, as flat bread that has not been doubled over in the oven by the baker for more strength. Alternate translation: “The people of Ephraim are like a cake that no one has turned over” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim is a flat cake that has not been turned over

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Ephraim” represents all the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Ephraim” represents the whole northern kingdom of Israel. These places refer to the people who live in them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim & Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “heart” refers to the whole person, emphasizing their emotions and desires. Alternate translation: “They are deceitful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Their heart is deceitful

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Ephraim” represents all the people of Israel. Also “wind” represents something that is useless or temporary. The people of Israel doing things that will not help them is spoken of as if they eat the wind. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim feeds on the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents the one who carries out an action. Alternate translation: “Through the prophets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: By the hand of the prophets

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hosea uses the term “Ephraim” to refer to the entire northern kingdom, although it was also the name of one of the ten tribes. Hosea seems to be speaking of a long-past time, when the northern kingdom was strong and honored, unlike at the present time. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: When Ephraim spoke

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people are represented by their “hands” to refer to the people making things. Alternate translation: “to the idols we made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: to the work of our hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: this is Yahweh’s declaration

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking about himself in the third person. This can be stated in the first person. Alternate translation: “from me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: from Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is speaking of himself in the third person. It can be stated in the first person. Alternate translation: “How can I” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: How can Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is the prophet speaking. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has rejected your calf” or (2) Yahweh is speaking. Alternate translation: “I myself have rejected your calf” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: Your calf has been rejected

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “they” still refers to the people of Israel. You can continue stating this is second person. Alternate translation: “if you escape” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: if they escape

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God is speaking about himself in the third person. It can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “Though they call to me, the Most High” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: Though they call to the Most High

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be restated to remove the abstract nouns. Alternate translation: “and do what is right, just, faithful, and merciful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: in righteousness, justice, covenant faithfulness, and mercy

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bloodshed” stands for “murder” which often involves making the victim bleed. Alternate translation: “you commit one murder after another” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: bloodshed comes after bloodshed

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **mockery**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “This is why people in Egypt will mock and laugh at Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: This will become their mockery in the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **wrath**, you can express the same idea with an adjective such as “angry.” Alternate translation: “I will not come to you and be angry with you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I will not come in wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the act of God having compassion is spoken of as if it were an object that someone experiencing that compassion had found. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **compassion**, you can express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “finds one who is compassionate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: finds compassion

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “which no one can measure or count” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: which cannot be measured or counted

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Where God said to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: It will be that where it was said to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will say to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: it will be said to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will gather them together” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: will be gathered together

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has shown you compassion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: You have been shown compassion

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that the people used to clothe themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: were used to cover her nakedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “are dying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: are being taken away

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language.
