Alternate translation: “My people are perishing because you, the priests, have not properly taught them about me so that they will obey me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: My people are being destroyed because of the lack of knowledge

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I have set a time of harvest for you also, Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: For you also, Judah, a harvest has been appointed

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “but the result will be that I will destroy the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: but it was only so they might be cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The Assyrians will carry them away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: They will be carried to Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The Assyrians will destroy the king of Samaria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Samaria’s king will be destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The Assyrians will destroy Israel’s high places, where the people acted very wickedly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The high places of wickedness will be destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The more I called them to be my people, the more they refused me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The more they were called, the more they went away from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Here “name” represents the entire character of God. Alternate translation: “is his name to which we pray” or “is his name by which we worship him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: is his name to be called on

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that the wind blows away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: that is driven by the wind away

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases can be put into the active voice. Alternate translation: “the enemy will dash their young children to pieces, and they will rip open the pregnant women” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: their young children will be dashed to pieces, and their pregnant women will be ripped open

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to prophets in general that God has appointed. Alternate translation: “Prophets are” or “True prophets are” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])
contextId.quoteString: The prophet is

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is describing a hypothetical situation. Here “ten thousand times” is an exaggeration that means no matter how many times he gave the people the law, they would still refuse to obey him. Alternate translation: “Even if I wrote down my law for them very many times, they would” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: I could write down my law for them ten thousand times, but they would

dublin_core.creator: Door43 World Missions Community
dublin_core.description: Open-licensed exegetical notes that provide historical, cultural, and linguistic information for translators. It provides translators and checkers with pertinent, just-in-time information to help them make the best possible translation decisions.
dublin_core.subject: TSV Translation Notes
dublin_core.title: unfoldingWord® Translation Notes

contextId.occurrenceNote: “15 pieces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: fifteen pieces

contextId.occurrenceNote: “2 days … day 3” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: two days & the third day

contextId.occurrenceNote: “10,000” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: ten thousand

index.name: Making Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information Explicit
Singular Pronouns that refer to Groups
